t: Habakkuk 1
The*p pronouncement that the prophet Habakkuk saw.
Habakkuk’s First Prayer
How*pn long, Lord,*s must I call for help and*ln you do not listen or*ln cry out to you about violence and*ln you do not save?
Why*ln do you force me to look at injustice? Why*ln do you tolerate wrongdoing? Oppression*ln and violence are right in front of me. Strife*ln is ongoing, and conflict escalates.
This*ln is why the law is ineffective and*ln justice never emerges. For*ln the wicked restrict the righteous; therefore,*ln justice comes out perverted.
God’s First Answer
Look*pn at the nations and observe— be*ln utterly astounded! For*ln I am doing something in your days that*ln you will not believe when*ln you hear about it.
Look!*ln I am raising up the Chaldeans, that*ln bitter, impetuous nation that*ln marches across the earth’s open spaces to*ln seize territories not its own.
They*ln are fierce and terrifying; their*ln views of justice and sovereignty stem*ln from themselves.

Their*ln horses are swifter than leopards and*ln more fierce than wolves of the night. Their*ln horsemen charge ahead; their*ln horsemen come from distant lands. They*ln fly like eagles, swooping to devour.
All*ln of them come to do violence; their*ln faces are set in determination. They*ln gather prisoners like sand.
They*ln mock kings, and*ln rulers are a joke to them. They*ln laugh at every fortress and*ln build siege ramps to capture it.
Then*ln they sweep by like the wind and*ln pass through. They*ln are guilty; their strength is their god.
Habakkuk’s Second Prayer
Are*pn you not from eternity, Lord*s my God? My*ln Holy One, you will not die. Lord,*sln you appointed them to execute judgment; my*ln Rock, you destined them to punish us.

Your*ln eyes are too pure to look on evil, and*ln you cannot tolerate wrongdoing. So*ln why do you tolerate those who are treacherous? Why*ln are you silent while*ln one who is wicked swallows up one*ln who is more righteous than himself?
You*ln have made mankind like*ln the fish of the sea, like*ln marine creatures that have no ruler.
The*ln Chaldeans pull them all up with a hook, catch*ln them in their dragnet, and*ln gather them in their fishing net; that*ln is why they are glad and rejoice.
That*ln is why they sacrifice to their dragnet and*ln burn incense to their fishing net, for*ln by these things their portion is rich and*ln their food plentiful.
Will*ln they therefore empty their net and*ln continually slaughter nations without mercy?
Habakkuk 2
Habakkuk Waits for God’s Response
I*pn will stand at my guard post and*ln station myself on the lookout tower. I*ln will watch to see what he will say to me and*ln what I should reply about my complaint.
God’s Second Answer
The*p Lord*s answered me: Write*pn down this vision; clearly*ln inscribe it on tablets so*ln one may easily read it.
For*ln the vision is yet for the appointed time; it*ln testifies about the end and will not lie. Though*ln it delays, wait for it, since*ln it will certainly come and not be late.
Look,*ln his ego is inflated; he*ln is without integrity. But*ln the righteous one will live by his faith.

Moreover,*ln wine betrays; an*ln arrogant man is never at rest. He*ln enlarges his appetite like Sheol, and*ln like Death he is never satisfied. He*ln gathers all the nations to himself; he*ln collects all the peoples for himself.
The Five Woe Oracles

Won’t*pn all of these take up a taunt against him, with*ln mockery and riddles about him? They*ln will say, “Woe*ln to him who amasses what is not his — how*ln much longer?— and*ln loads himself with goods taken in pledge.”
Won’t*ln your creditors suddenly arise, and*ln those who disturb you wake up? Then*ln you will become spoil for them.
Since*ln you have plundered many nations, all*ln the peoples who remain will plunder you— because*ln of human bloodshed and*ln violence against lands, cities, and*ln all who live in them.
Woe*pn to him who dishonestly makes wealth*ln for his house to*ln place his nest on high, to*ln escape the grasp of disaster!
You*ln have planned shame for your house by*ln wiping out many peoples and*ln sinning against your own self.
For*ln the stones will cry out from the wall, and*ln the rafters will answer them from*ln the woodwork.
Woe*pn to him who builds a city with bloodshed and*ln founds a town with injustice!
Is*ln it not from the Lord*s of Armies that*ln the peoples labor only to fuel the fire and*ln countries exhaust themselves for nothing?
For*ln the earth will be filled with*ln the knowledge of the Lord’s*s glory, as*ln the water covers the sea.
Woe*pn to him who gives his neighbors drink, pouring*ln out your wrath and*ln even making them drunk, in*ln order to look at their nakedness!

You*ln will be filled with disgrace instead of glory. You*ln also - drink, and*ln expose your uncircumcision! The*ln cup in the Lord’s*s right hand will*ln come around to you, and*ln utter disgrace will cover your glory.

For*ln your violence against Lebanon will*ln overwhelm you; the*ln destruction of animals will terrify you because*ln of your human bloodshed and violence against*ln lands, cities, and all who live in them.

What*pn use is a carved idol after*ln its craftsman carves it? It*ln is only a cast image, a teacher of lies. For*ln the one who crafts its shape trusts in it and*ln makes worthless idols that cannot speak.
Woe*ln to him who says to wood: Wake up! or*ln to mute stone: Come alive! Can*ln it teach? Look!*ln It may be plated with gold and silver, yet*ln there is no breath in it at all.
But*pn the Lord*s is in his holy temple; let*ln the whole earth be*ln silent in his presence.
Habakkuk 3
Habakkuk’s Third Prayer
A*p prayer of the prophet Habakkuk. According to Shigionoth.
Lord,*spn I have heard the report about you; Lord,*sln I stand in awe of your deeds. Revive*ln your work in these years; make*ln it known in these years. In*ln your wrath remember mercy!
God*pn comes from Teman, the*ln Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah*ig His*ln splendor covers the heavens, and*ln the earth is full of his praise.
His*ln brilliance is like light; rays*ln are flashing from his hand. This*ln is where his power is hidden.
Plague*ln goes before him, and*ln pestilence follows in his steps.
He*ln stands and shakes the earth; he*ln looks and startles the nations. The*ln age-old mountains break apart; the*ln ancient hills sink down. His*ln pathways are ancient.
I*ln see the tents of Cushan in distress; the*ln tent curtains of the land of Midian tremble.
Are*ln you angry at the rivers, Lord?*s Is*ln your wrath against the rivers? Or*ln is your fury against the sea when*ln you ride on your horses, your*ln victorious chariot?
You*ln took the sheath from your bow; the*ln arrows are ready to be used with an oath. Selah*ig You*ln split the earth with rivers.
The*ln mountains see you and shudder; a*ln downpour of water sweeps by. The*ln deep roars with its voice and*ln lifts its waves high.
Sun*ln and moon stand still in their lofty residence, at*ln the flash of your flying arrows, at*ln the brightness of your shining spear.
You*ln march across the earth with indignation; you*ln trample down the nations in wrath.
You*ln come out to save your people, to*ln save your anointed. You*ln crush the leader of the house of the wicked and*ln strip him from foot to neck. Selah*ig
You*ln pierce his head with*ln his own spears; his*ln warriors storm out to scatter us, gloating*ln as if ready to secretly devour the weak.
You*ln tread the sea with your horses, stirring*ln up the vast water.
Habakkuk’s Confidence in God Expressed

I*pn heard, and I trembled within; my*ln lips quivered at the sound. Rottenness*ln entered my bones; I*ln trembled where I stood. Now*ln I must quietly wait for the day of distress to*ln come against the people invading us.

Though*ln the fig tree does not bud and*ln there is no fruit on the vines, though*ln the olive crop fails and*ln the fields produce no food, though*ln the flocks disappear from the pen and*ln there are no herds in the stalls,
yet*ln I will celebrate in the Lord;*s I*ln will rejoice in the God of my salvation!
The*ln Lord*s my Lord is my strength; he*ln makes my feet like those of a deer and*ln enables me to walk on mountain heights! For*p the choir director: on stringed instruments.
